awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Middle Class Participation in the Marketized Eldercare Industry
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research project scientifically explores how behaviors and decisions related to housing and care during retirement are transforming as the eldercare industry becomes increasingly marketized. Market-based eldercare has expanded as the size of the aging population continues to increase, reliance on kin-based networks of care declines, and an expanding middle class orientation in consumer behavior has driven a preference for options in eldercare services. In focusing on the behaviors of a cohort first-generation middle-class retirees, the project aims to understand how older age experiences have been transformed by a transition to market-based alternatives and away from kin networks for older age housing and care. In addition to training a graduate student in methods of scientific data collection and analysis, it will also provide valuable material for professionals working in the fields of retirement planning and eldercare management. The project also broadens the participation of groups historically underrepresented in science. 

The doctoral student investigates the extent to which middle-class identity shapes decisions about eldercare in later life under conditions of market transformation, through an examination of the experiences of individuals who opt into privatized eldercare. The researcher will observe nursing home behaviors, tours, and care practices for older adults who live in a high-end nursing home. Older adults who can afford high-end nursing homes identify themselves as middle-class and distinguish themselves from others by consuming care services and goods including nursing homes. By conducting ethnographic research including participant observation, semi-structured interviews and case studies, this research asks how the marketized care industry, welfare policies, and all the choices and care practices shape the aging experience of the middle class. This research will further scientific understanding of the relationship between social class, commercialization, and eldercare.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the Cultural Revolution in the 1970s, the Chinese “middle class” was specifically targeted for destruction because they were regarded as the “enemy” of Communist society. However, after the economic reform, many previously middle-class individuals drifted back into work that used their prior skills, quietly maintaining a cryptic middle-class identity. Then, with the resurgence of capitalism, an explicit discourse emerged of needing to “rebuild” the middle class in China. Given the life-course trajectories of living in the Mao-era as middle-class, those with prior middle-class identities are older adults. Because of this, old age in China has become the canvas upon which the new middle-class identity is being painted. The state has dominated people’s lives, making it hard to plan for the future, including retirement, in this rapidly changing political situation. However, unlike the younger generation, middle-class older adults could look forward to receiving a stable pension. This situation alleviated their worries about the future and distinguished their lives from those of poor rural older adults or other blue-collar retirees who did not receive an adequate pension. The retirement home, rather than yielding to the biological pragmatism assumed in many places, has instead become a cultural icon. Therefore, older middle-class adults have reinvented their middle-class identity by choosing to live in newer, more expensive private retirement homes, distinguishing themselves from poor rural older adults with “no power, no economic power, and no culture.” Further, these similarly situated people have gathered to form a middle-class community. Tour groups visit retirement homes to witness and bask in middle-class life. Participating in domestic and foreign travel, a symbol of the middle class, and selecting one’s form of assisted living are cultural phenomena that reveal the middle-class privilege to choose how to enter old age in the eldercare market. Emphasizing their independent choice without their children's help is a way to prove that these older adults are an intellectual class that seeks new things, different from the conventional eldercare provided by their children based on filial piety. It is also a strategic choice to survive in a situation where it is difficult for the state and even children to take responsibility for their parents in old age due to China's rapid increase in the dependent population due to its one-child policy and the availability of commercial eldercare. Those living in retirement homes construct a cultural narrative and an ontological reality of what the middle-class is, not just for themselves but for society as a whole. In this study of one such retirement home, I ask: what is old age when it is the vehicle through which society-wide identity is being brokered? I conclude that, rather than settling into a continued middle-class identity, residents of my retirement home spend much of their time defining, enforcing and enacting the boundaries of class identity, and that they do so under the gaze not just of themselves and one another, but society at large.

This research contributes to anthropological theory by advancing the understanding of social class, capitalism in a post-socialist society, and eldercare. First, this study furthers the understanding of class formation and class identity. Specifically, it examines how older middle-class adults reconstruct their identity after retirement by looking at their socio-cultural capital and consumption of care-related goods and services. Second, rather than emphasizing the macro level of research about the post-socialist society, which focuses on the remaining government authority and collaboration with capitalism, this research broadens the understanding of the ways in which the features of post-socialism in China are reflected in its welfare policy. Finally, this study situates older adults as active subjects who manage their own care through consumption and enact their vision for later life.

This research concerns well-being in later life and the formation of middle-class identity through the choice of living places. This research aims to improve the well-being of the elderly by revealing the life history of the middle-class after the economic reform and elderly persons’ actual experiences with aging bodies, such as how they make decisions about where to live and what they consume in a marketized care system. Moreover, as this research sheds light on the life of a first-generation middle-class population in China, it contributes to documenting the history and everyday life of the middle class in a post-socialist country and demonstrates that the middle class is a highly heterogeneous group that includes generational variations. Finally, this research contributes to building more concrete welfare programs for older adults by examining how daily care for the elderly works and describing detailed examples of current practices in the Chinese care industry in the Chinese historical context. Thus, this study will help policymakers and social workers better understand the actual needs of older adults and the reality of the privatized care system they operate.
